title: API
description: Bienvenue dans ce cours sur les API.

body.raw:
Complete this course and earn ***10K free requests*** from our API :)

What is an API ?

Tutorial Basic
API stands for Application Programming Interface. It is a way for software to communicate with each other, much like a bridge that allows them to exchange information or perform actions for each other, without having to share all their code. This is an example of a doc site built using [ContentLayer](/docs/documentation/contentlayer) and MDX. This site is a work in progress. If you see dummy text on a page, it means I'm still working on it. You can follow updates on Twitter [@shadcn](https://twitter.com/shadcn). ## What is an API used for? An `API` is used to: 1. Enable communication between two software programs: For example, a weather app on your phone uses an API to get weather data from a server. 2. Automate tasks: An API allows you to perform certain tasks automatically (send messages, retrieve information, make transactions, etc.). 3. Facilitate development: Instead of coding each feature from scratch, developers can use APIs to integrate existing features (like online payments or geolocation) into their applications. ## How does an API work? To understand how an API works, let’s take a `restaurant analogy`. Imagine you’re in a restaurant. You’re the customer "like an app", and you want to order a dish. The `menu` represents what the restaurant offers, it’s like the `API Docs` that describes what the API can do. The `server` acts as the API: it takes your order, passes it to the kitchen "the internal system", and then brings you your dish. The API works in a similar way: it takes a request, passes it to another system, and then returns the response to the requester. As you prefer we can show that like this : | `Kitchen` | `Client` | `restaurant server` | Docs | | ----------------------- | ------------ | ------------------ | --------------- | | Database | You | API | Menu | ## Common Request Types in APIs APIs use requests to request or send data. Here are some common request types: - `GET` : Retrieves data (e.g., getting a user's information). - `POST` : Sends data to create something new (e.g., creating a new user account). - `PUT` : Modifies existing data (e.g., updating a user's profile). - `DELETE` : Deletes data (e.g., deleting a user account).
### Documentation This documentation site built using Contentlayer. ### Marketing The marketing site with landing pages. ### App The dashboard with auth and subscriptions. ### Blog The blog built using Contentlayer and MDX.
